titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Isham G. Harris Letters, 1861-1891
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, November 2021

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Correspondence of Isham G. Harris. Included in the collection are a letter, 1861, from John H. Savage, volunteering to organize Tennessee for Confederate support; a letter from A.S. Curry, Trenton, Tennessee, applying for the directorship of a bank there; and a letter, 1891, from Harris to Ben W. Austin, concerning a letter of General Albert Sidney Johnston.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Isham G. Harris letters, 1861-1891, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, November 2021.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Isham G. Harris was a Tennessee senator, 1847-1848, member of U.S. Congress, 1849-1851, Tennessee governor, 1857- 1861, and U.S. senator, 1877-1897

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Correspondence of Isham G. Harris. Included in the collection are a letter, 1861, from John H. Savage, volunteering to organize Tennessee for Confederate support; a letter from A.S. Curry, Trenton, Tennessee, applying for the directorship of a bank there; and a letter, 1891, from Harris to Ben W. Austin, concerning a letter of General Albert Sidney Johnston.
